articles.headline: Potential Flaw Seen in Design of Fallen Bridge
articles.snippet: In making public their suspicion about the flaw, officials were signaling a potentially crucial discovery and a safety concern for other bridges.
articles.abstract: In making public their suspicion about the flaw, officials were signaling a potentially crucial discovery and a safety concern for other bridges.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 8 — Investigators have found what may be a design flaw in the bridge that collapsed here a week ago, in the steel parts that connect girders, raising safety concerns for other bridges around the country, federal officials said on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Bush Faults Easy Money for Volatility
articles.snippet: President Bush described the economy as “thriving” and said lower taxes are the best way to guarantee prosperity.
articles.abstract: President Bush described the economy as “thriving” and said lower taxes are the best way to guarantee prosperity.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8  President Bush, seeking to reassure Americans about the economy and combat Democratic criticism of his policies, said on Wednesday that recent financial market turbulence was not a cause for worry but a natural adjustment from the improvident lending of recent years.

articles.headline: Johnson & Johnson Sues Red Cross Over Symbol
articles.snippet: Health care giant Johnson & Johnson has filed a lawsuit against the American Red Cross over rights to use the iconic symbol they have both shared for more than 100 years.
articles.abstract: Health care giant Johnson & Johnson has filed a lawsuit against the American Red Cross over rights to use the iconic symbol they have both shared for more than 100 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The red cross symbol is an icon of relief from disaster. For months, it has also been the subject of a festering disagreement between major American institutions: the health care company Johnson & Johnson and the American Red Cross.

articles.headline: Bankruptcy Trustee Sues Big Investor in Refco
articles.snippet: The Refco trustee seeks hundreds of millions of dollars in damages, claiming that the private equity that took Refco public should have known about the fraud that ultimately doomed the brokerage.
articles.abstract: The Refco trustee seeks hundreds of millions of dollars in damages, claiming that the private equity that took Refco public should have known about the fraud that ultimately doomed the brokerage.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trustee for Refco, a commodities brokerage firm that collapsed in fraud a few months after it went public in 2005, has sued Thomas H. Lee, the private equity firm that controlled Refco, saying the firm should have known about the fraud before it sold stock.

articles.headline: Internet Radio Made Easier
articles.snippet: Several new breakthrough portable consoles can tune in to thousands of Internet radio stations.
articles.abstract: Several new breakthrough portable consoles can tune in to thousands of Internet radio stations.
articles.lead_paragraph: You’ve heard of air pollution and noise pollution? Don’t look now, but another depressing form of toxicity is taking the fun out of life: ad pollution. That’s the creeping commercial crud that has sapped the pleasure out of TV, faxes, e-mail and, of course, radio. These days, it seems as though AM radio has 52 minutes of ads an hour.

articles.headline: From Two Broken Lives to One New Beginning
articles.snippet: HBO has publicized the stories of a man and woman’s decline into drugs and violence, but the tale of their shared redemption and coming marriage is less known.
articles.abstract: HBO has publicized the stories of a man and woman’s decline into drugs and violence, but the tale of their shared redemption and coming marriage is less known.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE, Aug. 2 — Donnie Andrews was a stickup man with a .44 Magnum who robbed drug dealers and was sentenced to life in prison for murdering one of them.

articles.headline: Islamic Finance and Its Critics
articles.snippet: The Dar al-Maal al-Islami Trust— a holding company with a portfolio of Islamic banks in Bahrain, Niger, Egypt and Pakistan — is trying to fend off charges that it has links to terrorism.
articles.abstract: The Dar al-Maal al-Islami Trust— a holding company with a portfolio of Islamic banks in Bahrain, Niger, Egypt and Pakistan — is trying to fend off charges that it has links to terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Before the attacks of Sept. 11, Prince Muhammad al-Faisal al-Saud felt welcome in America. A member of the Saudi royal family and a pioneer of Islamic finance, he was a pillar of a Saudi business establishment that has long relished its ties with the United States.

articles.headline: British Criticize Air Attacks in Afghan Region
articles.snippet: Civilian casualties caused by U.S. Special Forces make it hard to win over local people, a British commander said.
articles.abstract: Civilian casualties caused by U.S. Special Forces make it hard to win over local people, a British commander said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANGIN, Afghanistan — A senior British commander in southern Afghanistan said in recent weeks that he had asked that American Special Forces leave his area of operations because the high level of civilian casualties they had caused was making it difficult to win over local people.
